trial_identification.studytitle: The effect of communication during venous cannulation: a randomised controlled trial.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of communication on pain during venous cannulation: a randomised controlled trial.

conditions.healthcondition: Reducing patient discomfort during intravenous (IV) cannula placement

interventions.interventions:
The intervention involves communicating information prior to IV cannula insertion without using words with emotional negative content such as "sharp", "hurt" "sting". Ie. "I am about to insert the drip".
The intervention will be administered within 5 minutes of the IV cannulation.
interventions.comparator:
Control communication uses typical language currently used prior to insertion of IV cannula ie "I am about to insert the drip which is sharp and will sting a bit".
The control will be administered within 5 minutes of the IV cannulation.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Pain scores assessed by a verbal rating score.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Primary outcomes will be measured within 5 minutes of the IV cannulation

primaryOutcome.outcome: Pain scores assessed by a Likert score.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Primary outcomes will be measured within 5 minutes of the IV cannulation

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Secondary outcomes will be measured within 5 minutes of the IV cannulation.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Adults requiring the insertion of an intravenous cannula as part of their routine care.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Patients who require an interpretor or who have recently taken analgesia.

trial_design.concealment: Allocation concealment will be achieved using sequentially numbered opaque sealed envelopes (prepared independently from the research team) that are opened just prior to administering the intervention
trial_design.sequence: Computer generated random numbers in blocks prepared by the Department of Biomedical statistics at our institution
